segments.text: History 374, Semester Project, interview by Steve Brown.
Oh, interviewee is Sam Gideon, former general manager of the Lower Colorado River Authority, to be referred to as LCRA.
Question number one.
Who was most responsible for getting the LCRA started?

Well, it'd be pretty difficult to say who was most responsible because it was a culmination of efforts that had been going on for, oh, I guess 20 or 30 years, trying to create something that could be used in order to build dams above Austin that would control the floods that were devastating the river below Austin around Columbus and Eagle Lake and Wharton.
And the people down there had organized and tried to do something for many, many years, but I would guess that the one most responsible would be a man by the name of A.J.
Wertz, W-I-R-T-Z, who was a lawyer here in Austin, had been Undersecretary of the Interior under Ickes,
but had been interested in water development in Texas for many, many years.
Okay.
How much of an impact was the Tennessee Valley Authority on the formation of the LCRA?
Well, the Tennessee Valley Authority had no impact other than it was just an illustration of what could be done.
the reason for the LCRA was local and not based on anything that had happened over in Tennessee.
Okay.
Many people attribute the early economic growth of Central Texas, that is, after the
after the Great Depression to the LCRA.
Do you agree with that?

Well, I think that you would have to do that because the LCRA brought into the area a control of the floods that sort of would ruin the cities down below Austin, and including Austin, where it would ruin their water systems, their sewerage systems,
And then, in addition, the LCRA brought into the area a plentiful supply of water, which in Texas is something that is needed for growth.
And then the LCRA brought into the area a plentiful supply of low-cost electric power back in the 1940s.
when electricity could be bought at a much cheaper rate than it is now.
And by virtue of having the cheap lower rates, the people were able to take advantage of all these other things that I'm talking about in the way of water and flood control.
And it became a very desirable place in which to live.
There were no private homes?
private companies already involved?
There were private utilities already in Texas.
The city of Austin owned its own system, but the private utilities were having difficulties reaching out and going into the rural areas because it was too costly.
And what the LCRA did was take advantage of the laws that were being passed in the

under what was called New Deal under Roosevelt, where money was being made available to local cities and towns and rural areas so that they could either buy or build their electric systems because it was the feeling of Roosevelt that economical electricity was necessary in order to keep people on the farms and in order to keep the rural areas
to where they could continue to make a living and be a desirable place in which to live.
So what happened was that the LCRA, after it got started, bought out the area in Central Texas from the private utilities and developed the area itself.
Obviously, there was a lot of construction
And as you say, buying of people's lands.
What relationship or contact with environmentalists did the SRA have, or do they have now?
Well, back in 1940, wasn't anybody worried about the environment.
And there wasn't any contacts with the environmentalists as they are today.
In the first place, the people were
When the authority started in 34, the people didn't have jobs.
They had to make a living.
They were in the Great Depression, and anything that would give jobs was looked upon with great favor.
In the second place, you didn't have all the industries and the automobiles and the airplanes and the factories and everything that today are state-owned.

affect the environment and therefore what was done back in 1934 and 40 in constructing dams and clearing the area for dams and reservoirs had no effect on the environment and furthermore the dams were built in the hill country above Austin and primarily the land was covered with cedar up there and it was a
very harmful to the people, cedar was.
It caused people to have hay fever.
It got on the land and took it over and grass wouldn't grow under it, so it was worthless.
And it was good to get it cleared off.
You said that the LCRA helped in times of flood.
How does it help in times of drought?
Well, in times of drought, what it does, it takes the waters that have been stored during flood times, and it releases those waters gradually as they are needed downstream.

So in drought times, they let water out of the lakes in order to take care of needs of municipalities like Austin and on downstream, and then primarily to take care of the rice crop that grows down in the
area around Columbus and Wharton and Eagle Lake and Bay City.
Back before the dams and the LCRA, they were able to raise the rice crop about once every three years.
And then the other years, they might or might not have enough water.
After the LCRA, they were able to plan on raising the crop every year and have been able to do that.
And the amount, the value increased

uh from the standpoint of raising crops have been many millions of dollars every year in addition the land has become more valuable that's helped the local areas the local school systems the local cities and counties and in addition it keeps the people busy every year because they know they're going to get a crop they know there's enough water as an example during the draft
In the early 50s, there'd been about 10 years there when there really wasn't very much rain in Texas.
And the LCRA nearly had to drain their lakes to keep enough water going downstream, but they did that and then finally it rained.
So during the drought, what they do, they let water out that they caught during floods.
When the SRA was formed, it is a state agency.
It is a state agency created by the legislature of the state of Texas.
Well, there's obviously some politics involved, but how much political mingling is there?
I mean, is there certain administrators that get involved in it and try to influence people in some way?
Well, of course, there's a lot of politics involved in anything that's done.
You've got several river authorities in Texas.

There's the Brazos River Authority and the Trinity River Authority and Guadalupe River Authority and the Nueces River Authority, San Antonio River Authority, and several others, and all of them involve politics.
The LCRA probably involved more politics because it was being created and it's the only one at that time that had any electric power.
And so therefore, the private utilities, electric utilities, didn't want to see it built because they didn't want it competing with them for electric customers.
And there was a great deal of politics involved and trading back and forth.
And finally, it was worked out.
Everybody seemed to think probably is the best thing.
And then it brought about flood control.
product of what they were doing, too.
As a state agency, is there much influence on turning a profit in the LCRA with its electric power?
Is there much what?
Is there much incentive for turning a profit?
Oh, no, because the law that creates the authority says that it shall not make a profit.

All that it does is make enough to pay its expenses and to keep its facilities, equipment, and property in good shape and make enough so that it can continue to build for the future in order to meet the needs of customers.
But the act provides that it shall not make a profit.
And while it makes money from the standpoint of selling electricity and selling water,

that money must be used in paying its expenses paying off the debt that it borrows to build the dams and and the power plants and the transmission line and to build for the future so that the people that are relying on the lcra will not all of a sudden find out that they don't have any body to supply them with power and water uh what
is the relationship between the federal government and the LCRA.
Well, the federal government, there is no relationship from the standpoint of politics.
The LCRA was created by the state legislature.
The members of the governing board, it's run by a board of directors.
They are all appointed by the governor of Texas.
They have to be approved by the state senate.
And the federal government has nothing to do with that.
When the LCRA was started, there wasn't any place you could borrow any money, except from the federal government, because the banks wouldn't loan you any money.
And the private people didn't have any money to buy bonds to help construct dams and things like that.
So the only place you could go to borrow money was to the federal government.
And that's what the cities were doing.
The municipal buildings were being built by federal money.
The federal agencies were created, Public Works Administration and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation created in Washington the loan money so that it would put people back to work.
And so the LCRA went to the federal government to borrow their first money.
The legislature that created the authority gave the LCRA $15,000.
and to get started on, and said that had to be paid back out of the first month, and said that it could not levy a tax.
So the only way it can borrow any money is to agree to pay it out of the revenues that it made.
So the authority went to the federal government and borrowed the money to get started.
And that's where the, and in order to build rural lines and help the rural electric cooperatives,
The LCRA later borrowed money from the federal government.
But the only relation was that in the borrowing of money, the federal government had no regulations, no right to say anything to the authority about how it was run, what it did, or anything else.
And in 1942, the LCRA paid back the government

the money that it had borrowed and went into the open market in New York City and borrowed money on the bond market because by then it had gotten to where it could borrow money publicly and the recession was getting over and the war was on and there was money available to be loaned to build electric plants and dams and transmission lines and things like that.
In 1958, the then Senator Lyndon Johnson said, Of all endeavors on which I have worked in public life, I am proudest of the accomplishments in developing the lower Colorado River.
How much influence did Johnson have in the LCR?
Well, Johnson, from the standpoint of having influence, what he did was help the authority in Washington when they needed help to get started.
because he, the congressman in Texas, at the time the LCRA got started, Texas had some very powerful congressmen.

They had Sam Rayburn, who later became Speaker of the House, and then in the LCRA district, Buck Hannon was from Brenham, that's in the district, and he was chairman of the Finance Commit, Appropriations Committee, and then
The man from Columbus was chairman of the Committee on Building Dams.
And so they were very helpful in getting the money needed by OCRA to get started, getting loans made to them.
And then after they died, Johnson was elected congressman from this area.
And he was very helpful in getting

the money loan to LCRA so that it could build these dams and build the rural lines because when he became congressman while very few people out in his district had electric power out on farms or ranches and by the time he got through and got elected to the Senate practically every farm in his area that wanted power had electric power.
So what he did was to
help in Washington get a LCRA where it could borrow the money, which it paid back in full with interest.
But he got it when they couldn't borrow money anywhere else because money wasn't available.
Getting off the subject of the LCRA, since we mentioned Johnson, you were a personal friend of his.
What kind of a man was he?
What do you think?
I mean, that's a broad question.
Well, that's a broad question in a way.

The only answer I have is that, yes, I knew him from, I lived right across the street from him when long before he got, I mean, before he got elected to Congress and knew him while he was a congressman and worked with him on, he helped us with the LCRA and
And as far as I was concerned, he was always my friend, very nice.
His family was nice.
We'd go to Washington.
He'd invite us out to his home.
When he was president, he invited my son, myself, down to the White House and had them show us the White House.
And I never did have too much other business dealings with him.
So I wasn't around him in a political way because I never did run for office and never did
get involved in races other than donating money and time and driving my car and blowing the horn when they made speeches back in those days.
All the candidates had to go out to the various country fairs and all their friends went along, you know, and blew their horns when they made speeches trying to make noise.
But I didn't really get involved with him, politically speaking, so he was a very
a nice friend to me, and his family has always been nice and friendly.
He never did ask me to do anything.
When I was manager of OCRA, he would recommend people, but if we didn't hire him, that was all right, too.
So actually, I cannot pass too much on his type of man he was,
from a political standpoint because I wasn't associated with him politically and I wasn't associated with his financing part.
So I really don't know that much.
It's just as a neighbor that I knew him and he was always neighborly and friendly and would help if you needed a little help.
That's about all I know.
Okay, getting back to the LCRA,
It is a major electric power producer in the Hill Country area.
Has it ever looked into or thought about other forms of energy, as nuclear energy or solar energy or something?
Oh, yes.
In fact, they're in other energy.
In 1964, they built their first coal plant because
There's not enough water on the Colorado River to generate enough electricity to take care of the need.
So they built a coal plant and then they built another coal plant down here in Fayette County near LaGrange and they're talking and planning now to build a lignite plant.
They have looked at nuclear energy and of course
Solar energy is something nice to talk about, but it's just not practical as yet and probably won't be for another 20 or 30 years.
And you can't sit and wait 20 or 30 years because people want their electricity when they want the lights to burn and the television to run.
They don't want it 20 years from now.
So yes, they've looked at other things.
And as I say, there's not enough water
to generate any more power, water power.
So they've turned to coal, and they have two coal plants now, and they're getting ready to build a big lignite plant.
What exactly are we talking about in terms of amount of electricity being served to people and water available to the people?
Some broad amount.
How much are we talking about?
Well, I don't know.

and exactly how to measure it from the standpoint of electricity, but they sell electricity to about 30 towns in central Texas, all the way from Brenham and Smithville and Bastrop up to San Samba, Kerrville, San Marcos, Georgetown, Hattiesville, and towns like that, Luling.
Then they serve 10 electric cooperatives that serve about, I guess those cooperatives serve about, oh, several hundred thousand people on farms and ranches.
And then the towns they serve, I'm sure, half a million people.
So you're talking about lots of power and enough to serve,

Well, you're not talking about, say, as much power it would take to serve the city of Houston, but you're talking about enough power that would serve, say, the city of Brown, which owns its own electric system, and I think serves College Station.
The LCRA probably has about 20 times as much power as they do, and that's just a real rough guess.
It may be much more than that.
Okay, you joined the LCRA in 1940?
Yes, but I was working for Mr. Wertz in 1934 when the LCRA Act was written, and I was sort of carrying the books and things like that while he was general counsel from 34 to 40.
Then when he went to Washington as undersecretary of the interior in 1940, I became general counsel, and then
Stayed that way until 48, and then I became assistant general manager.
And then in 1956, I became general manager and stayed there until I retired in 1973.
So actually, I worked for the LCRA more or less full time from 1940 to 1973.
And you are somewhat still involved with them?
No, not now.
I don't do anything.
I'm retired.

in 19 when i went with them in 1948 they didn't have a retirement system and i felt like in order to get good employees you had to have one so i set up a retirement system and since it was the first one in texas for a public agency while we had to take it all the way to the supreme court be sure that it was valid and we did and then the court held that that it was valid as i set it up so uh
we put in the retirement system that when a man got to be 65, he had to retire.
And of course, at that time, I didn't think I'd ever be 65.
But when the time came, like everybody else, I had to retire.
And then when you retire, I've done a few things for them when things have come up involving something 20 or 30 years ago that nobody else knew about.
And then I've read,
bills introduced in the legislature and told them what the effect would be.
But other than that, I'm not connected with them at all.
I'm just on a retired basis.
The LCA was the first state agency to have a retirement program?
To have a retirement program that was carried by an insurance company.
Ours is
Prudential Insurance Company and other companies, they get it by virtue of bidding on the premium.
And I believe ours was the first one because I know that we had to go to the Supreme Court to establish that we had a right to take money and use it for our retirement system.
Now, the reason was, you see, we were taking money that we collected as revenues.
Now, if the legislature wanted to appropriate money, they could do that and set up a retirement system.
But you couldn't take revenue money until the LCRA tested it out and found out that you could.
You said that you were involved with the LCRA since 1934.
How much change have you seen?
Obviously, there's been tremendous change.
Well, the primary change, of course, is just in numbers.

And then also the change in the fact that back in 1934 everybody thought that the Colorado River would always have enough water to take care of the electric needs, but what no one expected in 1940 was that after the war was over you had such a pent-up demand for equipment that would use electric power that
And then when the rural areas came on, people started using from 5, 10, 15, 20, and 50 times as much electricity, and nobody had anticipated anything like that.
And so the main change has been in the way people use electricity now from the way they used it back in 1930 and early part of 1940.
You didn't have electric refrigeration.
I mean, you had a little of it, but not much.
You didn't have air conditioning.
You didn't have television.
You didn't have many, many things.
You didn't have electric dryers, washers, washing machines.
You didn't have on the farms electric milking machines.
You didn't have so many things that have been brought on.
The main change is the fact that
living has just been made more comfortable by having lots of electric power available.
Another great change is the use of the lakes for recreation purposes.
When they first came out, the lakes were there, nobody much went up to the lakes, but my goodness, after 1940, everybody had to buy a boat, everybody had to have a cabin on the lake, and
has figured that at least a million people a year use these lakes.

They're free, and it's brought about a tremendous impact on the economy, but as well as the general welfare and the happiness of the people, the fact that these lakes are here, available for recreation.
After the war, recreation became more available to people, and that's a great change from what it was in 1930 and 1940.

Another change that during the war the LCRA worked with all the private utilities because of the need for more and more power and particularly in Houston because they were being loads were being dumped on them for building for the war effort and as a result the
Private Utilities and LCRA worked up a very fine working relationship.
And they've worked together and continue to work together.
They have their lines interconnected.
They can help each other during emergencies.
They can help each other during storms.
They can help each other if they need help
because of unexpected loads, and that is what's going on now in Texas.
Everybody in the electric business is helping each other for the benefit of the state and the benefit of the people that are being served.
And that was not so in 1940 and 1930, but primarily because it wasn't needed then.
And during the war, when we had so much demands and so unexpected demands, it became necessary for all of them to be interconnected and work together.
And they've been doing that now since 1915.
It's just worked out fine for everybody.
The private connector companies
are turning more and more to coal power, aren't they?
Well, everybody is, because the federal government kept trying to make Texas give away their gas, so to speak, kept the price so low.

that everybody in the north and east started buying gas, and then the gas supply went down, and then the federal government got scared and said that you couldn't build any more gas plants, gas-fired plants, for generating electricity.
So you either had to go to oil or coal.
And when they started going to oil, the price of oil went out the ceiling, and you had the...
the threat from the Near East and they raised the price so coal became the...
